title: French destroyer Mameluk (1909)
text:
Mameluck was one of seven s built for the <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> in the first decade of the twentieth century.
Design and description.
The "Spahi"-class was over 50 percent larger than the preceding to match the increase in size of foreign destroyers. "Mameluk" had an <a href="length%20between%20perpendiculars">length between perpendiculars</a> of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , and a <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . The ships displaced at <a href="deep%20load">deep load</a>. Their crew numbered 77–79 officers and men.
"Mameluk" was powered by two <a href="Marine%20steam%20engine%23Triple%20or%20multiple%20expansion">triple-expansion steam engines</a>, each driving one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a> using steam provided by four <a href="du%20Temple%20boiler">du Temple boiler</a>s. The engines were designed to produce which was intended to give the "Spahi" class a speed of . During her <a href="sea%20trial">sea trial</a>s, "Mameluk" reached a speed of . The ships carried enough coal to give them a range of at a cruising speed of .
The primary armament of the "Spahi"-class ships consisted of six <a href="Canon%20de%2065%20mm%20Mod%C3%A8le%201891">Modèle 1902</a> guns in single mounts, one each fore and aft of the <a href="superstructure">superstructure</a> and the others were distributed <a href="amidships">amidships</a>. They were also fitted with three <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s. One of these was in a fixed mount in the <a href="bow%20%28ship%29">bow</a> and the other two were on single rotating mounts amidships.
Construction and career.
"Mameluk" was ordered from <a href="Ateliers%20et%20Chantiers%20de%20la%20Loire">Ateliers et Chantiers de la Loire</a> and was <a href="Ship%20launching%20and%20naming">launched</a> at their <a href="shipyard">shipyard</a> in <a href="Nantes">Nantes</a> on 13 March 1908. She was completed in June 1911.
Tasked with escort duties in the Mediterranean "Mameluck" was assigned to the 1st Squadron in June 1911, and a year later she was assigned to the 2nd Destroyer Squadron, of the 1st Fleet. In March 1913 she was assigned to torpedo squadron patrols and to support submarines in the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic</a>.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, "Mameluck" rammed the French destroyer "<a href="French%20destroyer%20Fantassin">Fantassin</a>" in the <a href="Ionian%20Sea">Ionian Sea</a> on 5 June 1915, so badly damaging "Fantassin" that the French destroyer consequently scuttled her.
In 1916, "Mameluck" escorted the <a href="submarine">submarine</a>s "Faraday" and "Le Verrier" to <a href="Milo%2C%20Italy">Milo</a>. On 14 December 1917, along with "Lansquenet", she sank the <a href="Imperial%20German%20Navy">Imperial German Navy</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> off <a href="Lefkada">Cape Ducato</a> in the Ionian Sea after the submarine <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed and sunk the French <a href="protected%20cruiser">protected cruiser</a> .
"Mameluck" was sold for scrap in 1928.
